title: County Executive Aims to Boost Service-Minded Candidates
summary: Assistance will be offered to veterans, as well as first responders and other essential workers. When Pat Ryan campaigned for Congress in 2018, the West Point graduate got invaluable help from national groups dedicated to supporting veterans running for office.

title: Plant-Tech Firm Benson Hill Going Public in $2 Billion SPAC Merger
summary: Deal's expected cash proceeds of roughly $625 million will accelerate Benson Hill's bid to bring down plant-based food costs, CEO says. Benson Hill Inc. is going public by merging with a special-purpose acquisition company in a deal that values the plant-growing technology firm at $2 billion, the companies said.

title: U.S. Pipeline Shutdown Exposes Cyber Threat to Energy Sector
summary: For years, security officials and experts have warned about the energy infrastructure's susceptibility to cybercrime. The ransomware attack that forced the closure of the largest U.S. fuel pipeline this weekend showed how cybercriminals pose a far-reaching threat to the aging, vulnerable infrastructure that keeps the nation's energy moving.

title: Department of National Child Care
summary: The Biden plan would cause costs to explode for little benefit.. Do you like the rising cost of health care and higher education, even as government subsidies also rise? Then you'll love President Biden's new plan for national child care.

title: Times Square as 'the O.K. Corral'
summary: Cuomo's analogy turns out to be apt, albeit for the wrong reason.. Gov. Andrew Cuomo recently denounced the Supreme Court for taking up a New York gun-rights case because "the streets of New York are not the O.K. Corral." He may want to retire that analogy because the city's streets are looking more like Tombstone all the time despite having one of the nation's strictest gun laws.

title: Lockdowns Didn't Stop Covid
summary: A new study finds more virus spread inside homes than work places.. Covid-19 lockdowns shaved 3.5% off U.S. GDP in 2020 even as the federal government spent more than $2.6 trillion in relief measures. Millions of children fell behind in learning and nearly 100,000 businesses closed for good.

title: Elon Musk on 'SNL' Says He Has Asperger's, Jokes About Dogecoin
summary: Cryptocurrency was trading lower after the Tesla CEO called it 'a hustle' in a sketch. Elon Muskkicked off his "Saturday Night Live" hosting debut finding a new target to mock: himself.

title: Breakout Cities Energize U.S. Economic Recovery
summary: Resume Subscription. GREENVILLE, S.C.-The pandemic is accelerating growth in midsize cities, positioning them to lead the charge in the nation's economic rebound.

title: The Trade Two-Step as Part of Biden's Diplomatic Dance
summary: The president can't afford to ignore trade, lest friends in Asia conclude they should work with China.. President Biden's new international policy is missing one big pillar: trade. The administration would like to dodge the politics; Democrats have only a narrow majority in Congress, and the party includes many economic isolationists. But America can't afford to drop out of the competition to write the world's new trade rules and commercial designs.

title: Patent Busting Won't Help Vaccinate the World Faster
summary: The solution is to ease restrictions on exporting shots and build more production capacity.. While the U.S. Covid pandemic has been contained, the situation in many countries, particularly India, is dire. It's essential to get as much of the world vaccinated as quickly as possible to save lives and prevent new variants from emerging. The Biden administration's support for breaking vaccine patents is a bad precedent that would do no immediate good and substantial long-term harm.

title: Biden May Make a Big Missed Steak
summary: The war on meat is no figment of the right-wing imagination.. Larry Kudlow suggested the other day that the Biden administration may declare war on meat. On his Fox Business show, the former Trump economic adviser lampooned a climate-change study from the University of Michigan, which argues that to cut greenhouse-gas emissions, Americans will have to cut back severely on "red meat, poultry, fish/seafood, eggs, dairy, and animal based fats." To which Mr. Kudlow quipped: "OK, got that? No burger on July 4. No steaks on the barbecue. I'm sure Middle America is just going to love that. Can you grill those brussels sprouts?"

title: El Salvador and Court-Packing Democrats
summary: Does the White House have the credibility to stop President Nayib Bukele's power grab?. If Democrats pack the U.S. Supreme Court, they will do irreparable damage to the institution. But the harm wouldn't end there. President Biden's commission to study the idea is already undermining U.S. moral authority on the rule of law and the separation of powers in Latin America.

title: Notable & Quotable: Lockdown Liberal Loners
summary: 'When vaccinated adults refuse to see friends indoors, they're working through the trauma of the past year.'. From "The Liberals Who Can't Quit Lockdown" by Emma Green, the Atlantic, May 4:

title: 'Metabolical' Review: Is It Something I Ate?
summary: Doctors rarely urge lifestyle changes on their patients, especially changes in eating habits. Not all calories are the same.. Amazingly, medical schools in the United States focus very little on nutrition. The topic, according to one study, gets less than 1% of the classroom time that aspiring physicians are required to sit through over four years-even though the foods and beverages people ingest are far and away, in America, the biggest drivers of disease.

title: Economy Week Ahead: Inflation, Retail Sales, Industrial Production
summary: Look out for Chinese factory-gate prices, U.K. GDP, U.S. consumer prices. Inflation is in focus with this week's round of economic data.

title: The Venture-Capital Trends to Watch
summary: Those in the industry hope to sustain last year's growth. But there are problems under the surface.. Last year, venture firms raised more cash than ever before-and many in the industry predict the momentum will continue.

title: Biden Administration to Name Thea Lee to Top Labor Post
summary: Former AFL-CIO trade official will oversee the department's international affairs division.

title: Policy Makers Can't Agree on Causes of Shortage of Workers
summary: Republicans say enhanced unemployment benefits keep workers on sidelines, Democrats point to child-care and chip shortages.. Policy makers on Sunday debated the root cause of a growing shortage of workers that threatens to restrain the pace of economic growth while the U.S. emerges from the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Some Countries Shift Guidance on AstraZeneca Vaccine
summary: Health officials say calculations around the benefits of receiving the vaccine keep changing. Several countries have shifted their guidance in recent days on who should receive the AstraZeneca PLC vaccine, as public-health officials continue to weigh the risk of the vaccine against the prevalence of Covid-19 cases.

title: The New Scientific Method: Identity Politics
summary: The National Academy of Sciences fights bias by explicitly introducing more of it.. The Biden administration is considering a laudable major expansion in funding for scientific agencies to shore up America's research base. The money will help, but it doesn't obviate the need to scrutinize who will be leading the government's scientific efforts, as many of us did during President Trump's term in office. The current emphasis in academic hiring on affirmative action shouldn't be of concern here. We should expect that merit and accomplishment will guide promotion to the highest levels of scientific leadership. Even if the Biden administration may appear more in touch with the concerns of the scientific community, it isn't excused from the duty to appoint qualified people to leadership positions.

title: The No-Ownership Society
summary: If you buy an iPhone, why shouldn't you be able to do whatever you want with it?. Do you own an iPhone? I mean really own it, even after shelling out $799? Apple and Epic Games are in a battle royale, a trial that may, in part, decide who owns what. Increasingly, we don't own tech. Like beer, we only rent it. It's time companies stop perpetuating the illusion that consumers buy their products and can do what they want with them. Message me on Parler if you disagree.

title: Israeli Court Delays Ruling on Possible East Jerusalem Evictions
summary: Protests erupt over potential removal of Palestinian families, and police brace for more clashes. TEL AVIV-Israel's Supreme Court on Sunday postponed a court ruling on whether to evict Palestinian families from an East Jerusalem neighborhood, a step that comes as the contested holy city experiences its worst violence in years.

title: Melinda Gates Sought Divorce Lawyers in 2019
summary: The philanthropist had discussions with lawyers in October 2019 around when the Microsoft co-founder's ties to Jeffrey Epstein became public. The split between Bill and Melinda Gates, announced last week, has been in the works for a long time.

title: A Summer Stock-Market Strategy: Invest Defensively
summary: You can forget 'Sell in May and Go Away,' but still find a way to exploit the seasonal patterns in the stock market. Stock-market investors might want to "stay and play" this summer rather than "sell and go away."

title: Kentucky Derby Winner Medina Spirit Fails Drug Test
summary: The Derby champ faces disqualification if the test is confirmed. Trainer Bob Baffert denied wrongdoing and said he would enter the horse in the Preakness.. Kentucky Derby winner Medina Spirit failed a postrace drug test, trainer Bob Baffert said on Sunday, raising the prospect of a disqualification in horse racing's marquee event.

title: Infrastructure Talks Could Set Course of Biden Spending Plans
summary: President is hosting top lawmakers at the White House this week to discuss multitrillion-dollar proposals.

title: U.S.-Stock Funds Ride the Earnings Wave
summary: As markets rallied, stock funds rose an average 4.7% in April, to push their year-to-date gain to 13.5%. The investing world, like the real world, might not be quite "normal" yet. But it is getting there, if the stock market's performance is to be believed.

title: Tiny Pools Are Big in Cramped New York
summary: Demand for pools and spas for Brooklyn brownstones and Manhattan penthouses has soared. When Jersey City, N.J., resident Niki Turkington wondered how she and her family were going to make the best of Covid-era living, she remembered the good times she had spent with friends in their backyard hot tubs.

title: Is Liz Cheney the Republican Party's Future?
summary: Liz Cheney should be lauded for her honesty, integrity and principled leadership.. Regarding your editorial "Purging Liz Cheney" (May 5): Rep. Liz Cheney needs to be commended for her courage in following her conscience rather than her political party's direction in ignoring Donald Trump's selfish commitment to compensate for his re-election failure in November. We need more GOP members of Congress who will do what they know is right, regardless of their party's political preference.

title: Republicans Must Attract More Young Voters
summary: As long as the Republican Party emphasizes social matters that many of the younger generation do not believe in, they will get fewer and fewer votes.. In "The Left Brightens GOP Midterm Chances" (op-ed, April 22), Karl Rove gives good reasons why the progressive Democrats may lessen their chances for success in 2022 by their stances on issues like defunding the police. But Republicans are falling behind the Democrats in their appeal to younger voters because they identify Democrats as being for equality of the races, equality of the sexes as well as LGBT and abortion rights. As long as the Republican Party emphasizes social matters that many of the younger generation do not believe in, they will get fewer and fewer votes, as older voters decline in numbers

title: Threat to the Courts Is From the Democrats
summary: While dark money may bankroll briefs from amici who generally have little sway with the court, the briefs from members of Congress trying to intimidate the court are much more problematic.. Regarding David B. Rivkin Jr. and Andrew M. Grossman's "Sheldon Whitehouse Is No Friend of the Courts" (op-ed, April 30): Never one for subtlety, Sen. Whitehouse, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Federal Courts, held a recent hearing titled "What's Wrong with the Supreme Court: The Big-Money Assault on Our Judiciary." While dark money may bankroll briefs from amici who generally have little sway with the court, the briefs from members of Congress trying to intimidate the court are much more problematic. After all, the justices aren't blind to the fact that Congress has the power to pack the court, impeach justices, slash the judiciary's budget and even restrict the court's jurisdiction in accordance with Article III of the Constitution.

title: Alvin Bragg Leans on Harlem Roots in Manhattan District Attorney Race
summary: Resume Subscription. Growing up in Harlem during the 1980s crack epidemic, Alvin Bragg said he once found a homicide victim on his doorstep and was threatened with a knife to his neck. At age 15, he said he was stopped by police officers at gunpoint, searched and then let go without explanation.

title: SEC Chairman Sets Sights on Citadel Securities, Virtu
summary: Regulator questions payment for order flow, in which firms pay brokers such as Robinhood for opportunity to execute investors' orders. WASHINGTON-The electronic-trading firms Citadel Securities and Virtu Financial Inc. have become pillars of the stock market in recent years, rivaling the role played by stock exchanges.

title: Bomber Mafia Prevented a Bloody Invasion of Japan
summary: The alternative-the invasion-was expected to more than double American dead from the rest of the war.. In calling Gen. Curtis LeMay virtually a war criminal for carpet bombing Japanese cities, both the author, Malcolm Gladwell, of "The Bomber Mafia" (Books, May 1) and reviewer Paul Kennedy ignore the nearly 20 million people murdered by the Japanese throughout Asia, mostly civilians, the mass murder of prisoners of war-far more American and British prisoners than the Germans killed-and the bombing of hospital ships.

title: Afghanistan Bomb Attack on Girls Highlights Threat to Women's Education
summary: Kabul residents on Sunday buried dozens of schoolgirls killed by explosions outside a school. KABUL-Zainab Maqsudi, 13 years old, exited the library and walked toward the main gate of the Sayed Shuhada school to go home on Saturday when she was blown backward by an explosion. When she stood up, the air was thick with dust and smoke, and she was surrounded by shattered glass.

title: Tokyo Tests Olympic Stadium With Little Time to Spare
summary: Nine athletes who live outside Japan were granted an exception and permitted to enter the country as organizers prepare for this summer's Olympics.. TOKYO-A handful of athletes from as far away as the U.S. and the U.K. came to Tokyo for a track and field competition Sunday that served as a rare on-site test for a pandemic-constrained Olympics.

title: Biden Administration Looks to Ease Covid Restriction Guidance
summary: Biden administration officials signal government will relax mask-wearing recommendations. WASHINGTON-Biden administration officials said Sunday that the U.S. is entering a new phase of the pandemic in which many vaccinated Americans can begin returning to normal activities and signaled that the federal government will further relax mask-wearing recommendations as more people get shots.

title: Extremely Wealthy Person Hosts Live Television Show
summary: Elon Musk appears on 'Saturday Night Live,' causing a surreal buzz on TV and in the crypto world. Did you ever dream of seeing Elon Musk, the Tesla-designing, space-chasing crypto booster masquerade as a lovelorn Icelandic talk show producer? Me neither, but there Musk was, at week's end, on "Saturday Night Live," rotating through sketches and wigs as the program's guest host-another surreal event, maybe not as surreal as a mega-billion currency system based on a dog joke, to remind us that our world is a little sideways, and may possibly be, as Musk cracked in his opening monologue, "a video game...and we're all just computer simulations being played by a teenager in another planet."

title: Yield-Starved Investors Snap Up Muni Bonds
summary: Investors have put $39 billion into municipal-debt funds so far this year, the most over that period since 2008. Investors in search of higher returns and lower taxes are scooping up debt sold by state and local governments, pushing borrowing costs to near-record lows and boosting coffers from California to Connecticut.

title: How Can Companies Cope with Ransomware?
summary: A cyberattack on a U.S. pipeline operator has raised the profile of a form of malware in which computer systems are seized and attackers demand payment in return for unlocking the assets. A cyberattack that forced systems offline at the largest pipeline operator on the U.S. East Coast followed warnings from current and former government officials that ransomware threatens national security.

title: Economists Disagree Over How Much 'Herd Immunity' Needed for Recovery
summary: Some say world's economies could return to normal before such a critical mass of population is vaccinated or otherwise immune. As countries rush to get their citizens vaccinated, a debate is heating up among economists about how much herd immunity matters for the world's economic recovery-or even if it does.

title: Trump 2020 Election Lawsuits Lead to Requests to Discipline Lawyers
summary: Courts, licensing bodies consider whether attorneys abused the legal system in challenging vote results. Courts are weighing whether some of the failed legal challenges to the 2020 presidential election were frivolous or improper and warrant punishment for the lawyers who filed them.

title: 'Fortnite' Maker Targets Apple's 'Walled Garden' in Courtroom Fight Over App Store
summary: Epic Games has raised questions about the safety of the App Store; one witness said it's like 'bringing a plastic butter knife to a gun fight'. In its courtroom battle with Apple Inc., Epic Games Inc. is questioning a core tenet of the iPhone maker's App Store business: that its success relies upon rigorous policing of the platform.

title: The NFL Team Every Other Team Tries to Copy
summary: Stealing coaches and executives from the Los Angeles Rams has become an annual rite in football. And that's not the only reason they dominate football's offseason.. One team was predictably absent from the top of the latest NFL draft: The Los Angeles Rams. Their last first-round pick was in 2016. They don't have another until 2024. They traded away all of their first rounders from 2017 to 2023 in a series of megadeals, including one this offseason in which they traded their last first rounder-No. 1 overall pick Jared Goff-for quarterback Matthew Stafford.

title: The Future for Private-Equity Stocks Doesn't Rest on Taxes
summary: Tax policies have often been a major driver for the industry. But the state of affairs today isn't the same.. Taxes have long been a key element of the business of private equity. But while past tax regime changes have been big moments for the industry, that might not be the case for the Biden administration's proposals.

title: Apple AirTags vs. Tile: The Best Tool for Finding Your Lost Stuff
summary: Apple's $29 tracker helps you find your lost stuff better than the competition does-but it makes it even harder to find your way out of Apple's ecosystem. "Come on. I'm right here, inside your unnecessarily puffy coat. No, not that pocket-the one with the stale muffin crumbs and crumpled CVS receipt."

title: Behind a Wharton Program's Collapse: Lawsuits and Unpaid Bills
summary: Elite business school sued U.S. affiliate of India-based education company, accusing it of misleading students, keeping tuition fees and violating its trademark. Simon Heaton said he expected to get a prestigious credential from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School last year, after his company paid about $23,000 for him to take a two-week leadership course for human-resources executives.

title: Should Business-School Hopefuls Skip the GMATs? Some of Their Power May Be a Myth
summary: Some top companies have de-emphasized test scores-but not everyone got the message. For years, M.B.A. students and admissions experts believed that top consulting firms and investment banks wouldn't let job applicants even interview if their score on the GMAT-the standardized test required for most graduate business and management programs-was below a certain threshold. In recent years, that may have become a myth.

title: J&J Vaccine Pause Stoked Hesitancy That Threatens Covid-19 Vaccination Drive
summary: The 10-day halt in April deepened concerns of many who were reluctant to get vaccinated, according to inoculation sites and a recent survey. The 10-day halt in administering Johnson & Johnson's Covid-19 vaccine has made it harder to inoculate the hard-to-reach and hesitant, health officials said, complicating efforts to reach community vaccination goals.

title: Some Startups Went From Rescue PPP Loans to SPAC Windfalls
summary: Turnabout prompts disagreement among investors, executives over whether government loans should be repaid. Thousands of venture-capital-backed startups applied for U.S. government-assistance loans when the pandemic hit. Many of them then went on to raise hundreds of millions of dollars each by going public.

title: The Biggest Mistakes People Make With Social Security
summary: One of the most common and costly: worrying about dying too soon. Many Americans mismanage their biggest retirement asset: their Social Security benefit.

title: Summer Jobs for Teens Make a Comeback-But Not All Types
summary: It's easy to find a gig as a lifeguard. Demand is high for work in child care and food service, too. But teens and young adults are finding more competition for paid internships.. Mayson VanMeter hoped to switch gears from her cashier jobs to find a more career-oriented internship in human resources this summer, after her freshman year in college-but she hit a wall.

title: As Covid-19 Surged, Indian Teachers Died After Working Elections
summary: Hundreds of thousands of government employees worked at polls in Uttar Pradesh after unions tried to have vote postponed. DEHRADUN, India-After India's most-populous state went ahead with local elections last month, a wave of illness swept through schoolteachers who were deployed by the government to work at the polls. Many of them died, without access to healthcare or a coronavirus test.

title: The Mortgage Boom Is Fading
summary: A decline in demand is fueling price wars across the mortgage industry, pushing down profits. The housing market is as hot as ever. The mortgage market, though, is losing steam.

title: Consumers Feel the Pinch as Prices Rise
summary: Rising costs for everything from fresh fruit to freezers are shaping purchase decisions. Americans accustomed to years of low inflation are beginning to pay sharply higher prices for goods and services as the economy strains to rev back up and the pandemic wanes.

title: Remote Kindergarten Could Affect Children 'for Their Lifetime'
summary: Resume Subscription. HIGH POINT, N.C.-Of all the students who suffered learning loss during the Covid-19 pandemic and remote schooling, one grade level has educators very concerned: the kindergartners.

title: AT&T, Verizon and T-Mobile Challenge Robocall Rule
summary: The FCC measure to stop foreign scammers could block legitimate overseas calls, phone companies say. WASHINGTON-The nation's largest wireless carriers are lobbying to delay a new regulation on robocalls aimed at overseas scammers who make them, citing concerns that the rule could end up blocking legitimate calls.

title: Afghanistan Bomb Attack Kills at Least 50 People
summary: The attack on Shiite area amplifies concerns that Afghanistan will slip into sectarian violence as U.S. withdraws. KABUL-Militants killed at least 50 people and wounded more than 100 in three explosions targeting girls outside a school in a predominantly Shiite neighborhood in Kabul, officials said, an attack that could exacerbate sectarian tensions ahead of the U.S. military withdrawal from Afghanistan.

title: Chinese Rocket Returns to Earth Over Indian Ocean
summary: Re-entry eases days of anxiety that pieces would fall on densely populated areas. HONG KONG-Debris from a Chinese rocket re-entered Earth's atmosphere over the Indian Ocean, Chinese officials said, easing days of anxiety that pieces would fall on densely populated areas.

title: Bo, the Obama Family Dog Who Roamed White House, Dies
summary: The Portuguese water dog was a gift from Ted Kennedy. Barack and Michelle Obama said Saturday that Bo, a Portuguese water dog that lived with the family over two White House terms, died after battling cancer.

title: Shooting in Times Square Leaves Two Women and a Child Injured
summary: Saturday afternoon shooting in New York City adds to concerns about rising crime. NEW YORK-A 4-year-old girl in a stroller and two women were shot Saturday afternoon in Times Square, New York Police Department officials said, in an incident whose location and timing add to rising concern about gun violence and crime in the city.
